block.p: As weather permits, start cautiously removing winter mulch from perennial beds and protected shrubs or trees. Remove salt hay or evergreen boughs in stages.
Don't prune spring-flowering shrubs or trees now (it eliminates flower buds), but do prune deciduous trees and shrubs. Birches and maples should be fully leafed before branches are removed.
As weather permits, start cautiously removing winter mulch from perennial beds and protected shrubs or trees. Remove salt hay or evergreen boughs in stages.
Don't prune spring-flowering shrubs or trees now (it eliminates flower buds), but do prune deciduous trees and shrubs. Birches and maples should be fully leafed before branches are removed.
Prune grapevines before sap starts flowing.
Gradually remove soil that has hilled up about your roses, and begin pruning the bushes.
Cut second-year canes out of the raspberry patch. Thin out weak new canes.

It's not too late for cuttings of geraniums (especially the fragrant ones and ivy-leafed varieties), ageratums and coleuses for new plants. Plant seeds indoors for lobelia, browallia, petunias and other trailing annuals to hang on the porch or patio.

Sow annual seeds of old favorites -- zinnias, globe amaranth, cornflowers, marigolds, asters. Try new ones like Ammi majus, or bishop's flower, a white beauty much like Queen Anne's lace, perfect for cutting.
